elements.content: A new bulky pyrene-derived elongated cross-shaped organic scaffold was successfully incorporated into a highly porous, noninterpenetrated square-grid copper(II)−organic framework material with the unprecedentedly huge dimensions of 25.5 × 25.5 Å2, while the layer-to-layer NH···N interaction leads to a unique hydrogen-bonded 64.82-nbo net.
elements.clean_text: A new bulky pyrene-derived elongated cross-shaped organic scaffold was successfully incorporated into a highly porous, noninterpenetrated square-grid copper(II)-organic framework material with the unprecedentedly huge dimensions of 25.5 × 25.5 Å2, while the layer-to-layer NH⋅⋅⋅N interaction leads to a unique hydrogen-bonded 64.82-nbo net.

elements.content: A new bulky pyrene-derived elongated cross-shaped scaffold was successfully incorporated into a highly porous noninterpenetrating square-grid coordination polymer with the unprecedentedly large dimensions of 25.5 × 25.5 Å2. Because of the NH···N hydrogen bonds in layers, a unique hydrogen-bonded 64.82-nbo network was formed.
elements.clean_text: A new bulky pyrene-derived elongated cross-shaped scaffold was successfully incorporated into a highly porous noninterpenetrating square-grid coordination polymer with the unprecedentedly large dimensions of 25.5 × 25.5 Å2. Because of the NH⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds in layers, a unique hydrogen-bonded 64.82-nbo network was formed.

elements.content: A large number of wonders and advances have been made possible by the synthesis of porous metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) because they have a wide array of applications, ranging from gas storage to catalysis and drug delivery. Thanks to several effective engineering strategies, systematic fabrication of porous MOFs can be achieved through designer assembly from judiciously selected molecular building blocks. Conceptually, with regard to network topology, if the building blocks are larger, the resulting networks will expand: the larger the brick, the wider the network opening. Thus, an intriguing research topic is the synthesis of giant MOFs from the designed supermolecular building blocks. Compared with the use of large metal clusters as nodes, the creation of giant MOFs from very large organic scaffolds is challenging and, therefore, rare. In particular, because the desired highly porous giant MOFs mainly favor some default nets, the organic scaffolds only prefer high symmetry and high rigidity, even if they are very bulky. Therefore, the following questions arise. How can the large organic motifs be employed? To what extent can the networks be extended? How large are the openings? Can the degree of interpenetration be adequately controlled? To develop additional innovative solutions, involving these future giant MOF materials, the design and synthesis of the very bulky organic ligands will provide a route to these wonders, especially to the large aromatic, rigid multicarboxylate ligands.
elements.clean_text: A large number of wonders and advances have been made possible by the synthesis of porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) because they have a wide array of applications, ranging from gas storage to catalysis and drug delivery. Thanks to several effective engineering strategies, systematic fabrication of porous MOFs can be achieved through designer assembly from judiciously selected molecular building blocks. Conceptually, with regard to network topology, if the building blocks are larger, the resulting networks will expand: the larger the brick, the wider the network opening. Thus, an intriguing research topic is the synthesis of giant MOFs from the designed supermolecular building blocks. Compared with the use of large metal clusters as nodes, the creation of giant MOFs from very large organic scaffolds is challenging and, therefore, rare. In particular, because the desired highly porous giant MOFs mainly favor some default nets, the organic scaffolds only prefer high symmetry and high rigidity, even if they are very bulky. Therefore, the following questions arise. How can the large organic motifs be employed? To what extent can the networks be extended? How large are the openings? Can the degree of interpenetration be adequately controlled? To develop additional innovative solutions, involving these future giant MOF materials, the design and synthesis of the very bulky organic ligands will provide a route to these wonders, especially to the large aromatic, rigid multicarboxylate ligands.

elements.content: As part of our ongoing efforts in the design and synthesis of functional crystalline materials, herein we prepared a bulky elongated cross-shaped dicarboxylate building block, H2CIP, using a condensation-coupling reaction between 2,7-di-tert-butylpyrene-4,5,9,10-tetraone and 4-carboxybenzaldehyde in the presence of NH4OAc (Scheme ). For the engineering of MOF materials, to our knowledge, this new ligand is the longest dicarboxylate scaffold known to date. The advantages of the ligand are apparent. First, the cross-shaped skeleton with several aromatic rigid rings is bulky and highly symmetric. It offers more opportunities to achieve giant MOFs with default nets. Second, the dicarboxylate moiety helps to create a neutral framework without anions inside the extraframework space. Third, the bulky skeleton can rotate and has functional imidazole rings, which provide effective hydrogen-bond interactions that control the resulting molecular arrangements. We successfully incorporated CIP2− into a giant 44-sql framework, which has the following empirical formula: {[Cu(CIP)(H2O)]·4H2O·5DMF} n (MAS-1, MAS = Materials of Academia Sinica). Interestingly, this unique giant MOF consists of square grids with the unprecedentedly large dimensions of 25.5 × 25.5 Å2 (Figure ); however, it is still highly porous and noninterpenetrating.
elements.clean_text: As part of our ongoing efforts in the design and synthesis of functional crystalline materials, herein we prepared a bulky elongated cross-shaped dicarboxylate building block, H2CIP, using a condensation-coupling reaction between 2,7-di-tert-butylpyrene-4,5,9,10-tetraone and 4-carboxybenzaldehyde in the presence of NH4OAc (Scheme ). For the engineering of MOF materials, to our knowledge, this new ligand is the longest dicarboxylate scaffold known to date. The advantages of the ligand are apparent. First, the cross-shaped skeleton with several aromatic rigid rings is bulky and highly symmetric. It offers more opportunities to achieve giant MOFs with default nets. Second, the dicarboxylate moiety helps to create a neutral framework without anions inside the extraframework space. Third, the bulky skeleton can rotate and has functional imidazole rings, which provide effective hydrogen-bond interactions that control the resulting molecular arrangements. We successfully incorporated CIP2- into a giant 44-sql framework, which has the following empirical formula: {[Cu(CIP)(H2O)]⋅4H2O⋅5DMF} n  (MAS-1, MAS = Materials of Academia Sinica). Interestingly, this unique giant MOF consists of square grids with the unprecedentedly large dimensions of 25.5 × 25.5 Å2 (Figure ); however, it is still highly porous and noninterpenetrating.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Synthesis Route to the H<sub>2</sub>CIP Ligand</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="ic-2009-00786b_0001.tif"></graphic>

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis Route to the H2CIP Ligand

elements.content: MAS-1 was synthesized by the solvothermal reaction of CuCl2·2H2O and H2CIP in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) at 160 °C for 48 h as green crystals. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that MAS-1 crystallizes in the space group C2/m and affords a neutral square-grid network. As depicted in Figure , the grid with dimensions of 25.5 × 25.5 Å2 (measured between the midpoints of the Cu2 units) is built from paddle-wheel Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 clusters and bulky CIP2− ligands, which act as nodes and linkers, respectively. Although gridlike MOFs with a 44-sql type topology are simple, these materials have useful intrinsic properties that need to be explored. In particular, expanded gridlike networks with very large dimensions (>20 × 20 Å2) are currently limited. All of these networks, which are nearly cationic, are almost synthesized using long N,N′-type ligands. To the best of our knowledge, MAS-1 is the largest porous neutral square-grid coordination network known to date.
elements.clean_text: MAS-1 was synthesized by the solvothermal reaction of CuCl2⋅2H2O and H2CIP in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) at 160 °C for 48 h as green crystals. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that MAS-1 crystallizes in the space group C2/m and affords a neutral square-grid network. As depicted in Figure , the grid with dimensions of 25.5 × 25.5 Å2 (measured between the midpoints of the Cu2 units) is built from paddle-wheel Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 clusters and bulky CIP2- ligands, which act as nodes and linkers, respectively. Although gridlike MOFs with a 44-sql type topology are simple, these materials have useful intrinsic properties that need to be explored. In particular, expanded gridlike networks with very large dimensions (>20 × 20 Å2) are currently limited. All of these networks, which are nearly cationic, are almost synthesized using long N,N'-type ligands. To the best of our knowledge, MAS-1 is the largest porous neutral square-grid coordination network known to date.

elements.content: Ball-and-stick model of a huge square grid in MAS-1 (red = Cu, green = O, blue = N, light gray = C, and yellow = H).
elements.clean_text: 1  Ball-and-stick model of a huge square grid in MAS-1 (red = Cu, green = O, blue = N, light gray = C, and yellow = H).

elements.content: As a result of the geometric characteristics of the CIP2− ligand, the grids are virtually planar and noninterpenetrating (Figure ). The adjacent layers are stacked in an offset ABCABC manner, giving rise to two types of openings with effective dimensions of 5 × 5 and 2 × 2 Å2, as viewed from the grid plane (Figure a). Another interesting feature of MAS-1 is that the side-chain groups of the CIP2− ligand can protrude into the cavities of the adjacent sheets because of the layer-to-layer NH···N hydrogen-bond interactions (N···N = 2.94 Å). As shown in Figure , the NH···N hydrogen-bond interactions in layers give rise to a unique 64.82-nbo topology. To our knowledge, as of this writing, this type of hydrogen-bonded 44-sql framework is extremely rare. The layers slip along the c axis, with a slipping separation of 11.97 Å (one c-axis length). Moreover, rectangular channel openings with dimensions of 8 × 4 Å2 running along the c axis were apparent (Figure b). Seemingly, the ABCABC stacking pattern should reduce the free space in MAS-1, but the calculated density of MAS-1 (in the absence of all guests) is only 0.79 g cm−3. Analysis using the PLATON software indicated that the extraframework volume per unit cell is approximately 54.2%. If a long-chain linear ligand is employed in the creation of extended gridlike MOFs, interpenetration frequently occurs. Because of the intrinsic properties of the cross-shaped CIP2− ligand, interpenetration is not observed in MAS-1, despite the high porosity.
elements.clean_text: As a result of the geometric characteristics of the CIP2- ligand, the grids are virtually planar and noninterpenetrating (Figure ). The adjacent layers are stacked in an offset ABCABC manner, giving rise to two types of openings with effective dimensions of 5 × 5 and 2 × 2 Å2, as viewed from the grid plane (Figure a). Another interesting feature of MAS-1 is that the side-chain groups of the CIP2- ligand can protrude into the cavities of the adjacent sheets because of the layer-to-layer NH⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen-bond interactions (N⋅⋅⋅N = 2.94 Å). As shown in Figure , the NH⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen-bond interactions in layers give rise to a unique 64.82-nbo topology. To our knowledge, as of this writing, this type of hydrogen-bonded 44-sql framework is extremely rare. The layers slip along the c axis, with a slipping separation of 11.97 Å (one c-axis length). Moreover, rectangular channel openings with dimensions of 8 × 4 Å2 running along the c axis were apparent (Figure b). Seemingly, the ABCABC stacking pattern should reduce the free space in MAS-1, but the calculated density of MAS-1 (in the absence of all guests) is only 0.79 g cm-3. Analysis using the PLATON software indicated that the extraframework volume per unit cell is approximately 54.2%. If a long-chain linear ligand is employed in the creation of extended gridlike MOFs, interpenetration frequently occurs. Because of the intrinsic properties of the cross-shaped CIP2- ligand, interpenetration is not observed in MAS-1, despite the high porosity.

elements.content: Crystal structures of MAS-1: (a) space-filling representation of the top view of four square-grid layers showing the distinct openings with various sizes; (b) view of the stacking nets along the c axis; (c) side view of the stacking nets.
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structures of MAS-1: (a) space-filling representation of the top view of four square-grid layers showing the distinct openings with various sizes; (b) view of the stacking nets along the c axis; (c) side view of the stacking nets.

elements.content: Simplified stacking diagrams of MAS-1 highlighting (a) the unique layer-to-layer NH···N hydrogen bonds and (b) the distorted 64.82-nbo network topology.
elements.clean_text: 3  Simplified stacking diagrams of MAS-1 highlighting (a) the unique layer-to-layer NH⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds and (b) the distorted 64.82-nbo network topology.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of MAS-1 indicated a weight loss of 37% (calcd 38%) during heating from room temperature to approximately 230 °C, which corresponds to the loss of four water and five DMF guest molecules. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies imply that the square-grid layers of MAS-1 are capable of slight slipping with respect to each other, when the guest molecules are lost (two types of PXRD patterns were observed at approximately 50 and 150 °C). After desolvation at 200 °C, the PXRD patterns indicated that the peaks, after resolvation, gradually returned to those characteristic of the as-synthesized compound. The framework flexibility can be attributed to the unique layer-to-layer NH···N hydrogen bonds.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of MAS-1 indicated a weight loss of 37% (calcd 38%) during heating from room temperature to approximately 230 °C, which corresponds to the loss of four water and five DMF guest molecules. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies imply that the square-grid layers of MAS-1 are capable of slight slipping with respect to each other, when the guest molecules are lost (two types of PXRD patterns were observed at approximately 50 and 150 °C). After desolvation at 200 °C, the PXRD patterns indicated that the peaks, after resolvation, gradually returned to those characteristic of the as-synthesized compound. The framework flexibility can be attributed to the unique layer-to-layer NH⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: The available porosity of MAS-1 was verified by gas-sorption studies. A freshly prepared sample of MAS-1 was activated at 140 °C under vacuum for 16 h, showing a large weight loss of 35%, as expected. A nitrogen-sorption study indicated a typical type I isotherm with a Brunauer−Emmett−Teller surface area of 389 m2 g−1 and a pore volume of 0.109 cm3 g−1 (using the Dubinin−Radushkevich equation). In addition, the hydrogen adsorption isotherm indicates good H2 uptake of 97 cm3 g−1 (0.87 wt %) at 77 K and 1 atm.
elements.clean_text: The available porosity of MAS-1 was verified by gas-sorption studies. A freshly prepared sample of MAS-1 was activated at 140 °C under vacuum for 16 h, showing a large weight loss of 35%, as expected. A nitrogen-sorption study indicated a typical type I isotherm with a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area of 389 m2 g-1 and a pore volume of 0.109 cm3 g-1 (using the Dubinin-Radushkevich equation). In addition, the hydrogen adsorption isotherm indicates good H2 uptake of 97 cm3 g-1 (0.87 wt %) at 77 K and 1 atm.

elements.content: In conclusion, we successfully utilized a bulky elongated cross-shaped dicarboxylate ligand in the preparation of a highly porous square-grid giant MOF with the unprecedentedly large dimensions of 25.5 × 25.5 Å2. Because of the NH···N hydrogen bonds in layers, a unique hydrogen-bonded 64.82-nbo network was formed of a stacking of the 44-sql type layers. This giant MOF has well-ordered microporosity, thus exhibiting good hydrogen-storage efficiency. The incorporation of this type of bulky organic scaffold into other potential giant MOF materials remains an interesting, but challenging, research topic. Furthermore, using a suitable pillared ligand to replace the coordinated water molecules is certainly an acceptable approach for preparing a genuine MOF. Additional studies are currently underway.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we successfully utilized a bulky elongated cross-shaped dicarboxylate ligand in the preparation of a highly porous square-grid giant MOF with the unprecedentedly large dimensions of 25.5 × 25.5 Å2. Because of the NH⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds in layers, a unique hydrogen-bonded 64.82-nbo network was formed of a stacking of the 44-sql type layers. This giant MOF has well-ordered microporosity, thus exhibiting good hydrogen-storage efficiency. The incorporation of this type of bulky organic scaffold into other potential giant MOF materials remains an interesting, but challenging, research topic. Furthermore, using a suitable pillared ligand to replace the coordinated water molecules is certainly an acceptable approach for preparing a genuine MOF. Additional studies are currently underway.

elements.content: Crystallographic details in CIF format for MAS-1, experimental section, additional pictures, gas sorption, and TGA, PXRD, and IR data. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content:
For examples, see:

For examples, see:

Synthesis of MAS-1: A mixture of CuCl2·2H2O (34.7 mg, 0.2 mmol), H2CIP (31.7 mg, 0.05 mmol), and DMF (6 mL) was sealed in a 23-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr acid digestion bomb, heated at 160 °C for 48 h, and then cooled for 72 h. Green rhombic crystals of MAS-1 were formed in 48% yield (27.8 mg, based on H2CIP). The solid product was washed with deionized water and ethanol and dried in air. The PXRD patterns of the samples are in good agreement of the patterns simulated from the single-crystal diffraction data of MAS-1. Elem anal. Calcd for C55H77CuN9O14: C, 57.35; H, 6.74; N, 10.94. Found: C, 57.38; H, 6.59; N, 11.07. The formula [Cu(CIP)(H2O)]·4H2O·5DMF was assigned by elemental microanalysis, TGA, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies.

Green rhombic crystals of MAS-1 were formed in 48% yield (27.8 mg, based on H2CIP). The solid product was washed with deionized water and ethanol and dried in air. The PXRD patterns of the samples are in good agreement of the patterns simulated from the single-crystal diffraction data of MAS-1. Elem anal. Calcd for C55H77CuN9O14: C, 57.35; H, 6.74; N, 10.94. elements.content:
In order to identify uniquely nets and topologies, Mike O’Keeffe proposed a three-letter code as the codename for nets (similar to zeolite names). See:

Crystal data for MAS-1: C40H38CuN4O7 (for [Cu(CIP)(H2O)]·2H2O), M r = 750.28, monoclinic, C2/m, a = 17.214(1) Å, b = 35.418(3) Å, c = 11.973(1) Å, β = 124.662(4)°, V = 6004.0(8) Å3, Z = 4, ρcalcd = 0.830 g cm−3, μ = 0.398 mm−1, F(000) = 1564, T = 293(2) K. A total of 22 147 reflections were collected in the range of θ = 1.15−25.03°, of which 5162 were unique (R int = 0.1027). Final R indices: R1 = 0.0634, wR2 = 0.1724 for 2603 reflections [I > 2σ(I)]; R1 = 0.1221, wR2 = 0.1865 for 5162 independent reflections (all data) and 282 parameters, GOF = 0.946.

A total of 22147 reflections were collected in the range of θ = 1.15-25.03°, of which 5162 were unique (R int = 0.1027). Final R indices: R1 = 0.0634, wR2 = 0.1724 for 2603 reflections [I > 2σ(I)]; R1 = 0.1221, wR2 = 0.1865 for 5162 independent reflections (all data) and 282 parameters, GOF = 0.946.

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of MAS-1 indicated a weight loss of 37% (calcd 38%) during heating from room temperature to approximately 230 °C, which corresponds to the loss of four water and five DMF guest molecules. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies imply that the square-grid layers of MAS-1 are capable of slight slipping with respect to each other, when the guest molecules are lost (two types of PXRD patterns were observed at approximately 50 and 150 °C). After desolvation at 200 °C, the PXRD patterns indicated that the peaks, after resolvation, gradually returned to those characteristic of the as-synthesized compound. The framework flexibility can be attributed to the unique layer-to-layer NH···N hydrogen bonds.

The available porosity of MAS-1 was verified by gas-sorption studies. A freshly prepared sample of MAS-1 was activated at 140 °C under vacuum for 16 h, showing a large weight loss of 35%, as expected. A nitrogen-sorption study indicated a typical type I isotherm with a Brunauer−Emmett−Teller surface area of 389 m2 g−1 and a pore volume of 0.109 cm3 g−1 (using the Dubinin−Radushkevich equation). In addition, the hydrogen adsorption isotherm indicates good H2 uptake of 97 cm3 g−1 (0.87 wt %) at 77 K and 1 atm.

After desolvation at 200 °C, the PXRD patterns indicated that the peaks, after resolvation, gradually returned to those characteristic of the as-synthesized compound. The framework flexibility can be attributed to the unique layer-to-layer NH⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds.

metadata.title: An Unprecedentedly Huge Square-Grid Copper(II)−Organic Framework Material Built from a Bulky Pyrene-Derived Elongated Cross-Shaped Scaffold
